Long lingering oaky tartness in the aftertaste. Quite unique Cantillon.Earlier Rating: 8/14/2005 Total Score: 3.7Bottled 75cl
Deep hazy orange, not much head. Intensive aroma of leather. Sour, fruity, flavor of grapes and red currant.Earlier Rating: 8/14/2005 Total Score: 3.7Bottled 75cl @RBESG05
Pale yellow, hazy, not much head. Typical sour, dry Cantillon nose. Very bitter for a lambic, double amount of hops is used here. Double IPA with lambic one would say.

Bottle. High white fluffy and long lasting head. Slightly hazy amber body. Lemon vinegar hay sour aroma. Low carbonated relatively sweet and sour lemon oranges grapefruit flavor with a long aftertaste. Not as acidic as expected and feared. Earlier Rating: 6/29/2007 Total Score: 3.6Bottle. High white fluffy but quickly disappearing head. Hazy orange body. Fruity aroma of grape fruit and apples. Acidic without being sour fruity flavor with fresh and sharp edges. Long lasting lemon like aftertaste. No carbonation of course.

Bottle at bager.
Hazy golden coloured with a huge white head.
Fruity and light acidic aroma of grapes and hops.
Fruity and light acidic flavour of oak, flowers and hops.
Tart finish.Earlier Rating: 8/17/2005 Total Score: 3.3Bottled at RBESG 2005.
Hazy yellow coloured with a white head.
Acidic aroma with notes of fruits and lactic acid.
Acidic flavour of fruits and hops.Earlier Rating: 8/14/2005 Total Score: 3.5Bottled.
Cloudy amber coloured with a white head.
Acidic aroma with notes of woods and fruits.
Acidic flavour with lots of fruits and wood.

UPDATED: AUG 14, 2012 Bottle (as: Cuvée Saint-Gilloise) at Bagers 30 kg Party. Cloudy golden/amber - white head. Cheesy. Soapy. Fruity. Acid. Wooden. Light sourness. Very nice. Earlier Rating: 10/19/2006 Total Score: 4Bottle (as: Cuvee des Champions) at Ølbaren - just before a "Keiji Haino" concert - a very good concert by the way !!!  - shared with Mads and Jacob. Unclear golden - small white head. Very nice - fresh hopped. Gooseberries, light earthy, ligh barnyard. Dry. Lovely.

UPDATED: SEP 28, 2013 Révisitée en sept 2013, cask au ML, Fontainas.

Dorée comme les foins, col crémeux blanc.
Arôme offre un bouquet subtile et typique de Cantillon, de moût, houblonné fruité tropical et très fleuri. Difficile à décrire mais un pur plaisir.
Palais est citrique, très plaisant pour qui sait apprécier ce style. Profil type de lambic-grains, palais sec voire poussiéreux très prenant. Le tout est extrêmement rafraichissant avec une pointe citrique houblonné et presque de rhubarbe, feuilles vertes - pamplemousse. 8-5-8-4-17



Bottle @ Cantillon. 
Orangée avec qcq bulles qui viennent percer la surface.
Arôme fruité avec fleur de houblon laissant séchapper ces notes de dry-hopping du houblon Hallertauer qui rajoute cette touche original de fleuri et terreux de ce mélange lambic-gueuze.
En bouche, carbonation fine, palais est sec, je note encore ce côté houblonné-fleur/dry-hopped et des touches de fruits allant vers airelles, herbes. Le palais est aigre-doux avec encore qcq sucres résiduels. Au fini, une fine touche citronnée, abricot/agrumes avec un palais terreux 7-4-8-4-15.

Earlier Rating: 6/8/2008 Total Score: 3.9Lighlty golden / hazy. Bitter and sour at best, could say vinagry.
A nice Geuze, distinct taste, funky.

Draught at Akkurat, Stockholm.  Hazy golden, small head. Aroma of concentrated lamon and barnyard, some sweaty hops. Fresh and acidic with mildly sparkling mouthfeel. Tart and alive, quite hoppy for a Cantillon. Funky and citrid with long grape stone bitterness. Damn near perfect in this condition.Earlier Rating: 8/25/2005 Total Score: 4.4Bottled at RBESG. Hazy golden. Citric acid nose. Fresh and lively with notes of cobwebs and hops. Typical complex, tart Cantillon beer, but more hoppy, and with a surprisingly bitter finish.Earlier Rating: 10/22/2004 Total Score: 4.4Bottled. Lively golden appearance. Fresh hoppy, citric aroma. Distinct acidity (even for a Cantillon), light sparkling mouthfeel. Lemony and juicy with quite a lot of hop chracter. I am now a great fan pf Royal Union Sint Gilloise...

Hazy orange color, white head. Aroma of funk (barnyard), unripe gooseberries, lemon, green apples. Flavour is tart and dry with unripe gooseberries, green apples, lemon and the classic funky stable/barnyard notes found in lambic. Lively carbonation. Mediumbodied.

UPDATED: NOV 8, 2016 New rating from September 2016: draft for Zwanze Day 2016, Kernel brewery, London. It pours a hazed bright golden color with a medium white head. Aroma is funky tart lemony, quite complex and rich, plenty of lemon juice and peel, barnyard funk, horse blanket, mineral qualities, gooseberries. Taste is also funnky and acidic with more horse blanket and funky basement notes, mineral qualities with gooseberries and lemon peel and juice. Medium bodied with massaging carbonation. Overall, excellent. Score 4.1 
Original rating from March 2011: 375ml bottle. Pours a cloudy orangish/ color with a big bubbly white head. Aroma is mostly sweet-sour with oak and horse blanket qualities. Nice barnyard notes too. Taste is sweet/sour, almost lemon peel. Grassy earthy notes. Some bittering hops. Medium bodied and lots of carbonation. Definitely not as sour as it could be. Still nice though. Score 3.9

@ Cantillon. Orange coloured. Unclear. Earthy grape sourness in the aroma with a touch of barnyard. Flavour is sourish and grapy. Has a herbal edge and again a light barnyard. Medium to full bodied. Sourish and grapy end. Quite smooth and easy to drink.Earlier Rating: 10/20/2004 Total Score: 4.3Bottled: Orange coloured. Small off white head. This has all the things I love about Cantillon. Tart, earthnotes, light fruitnotes, great sourness balanced by a subtle sweetness. Is very refreshing and cleansing. Balanced and complex as hell. A true great one. Earlier Rating: 6/17/2004 Total Score: 4Bottled: Orange coloured. Unclear. Small beige head. Earth, tart, wood, sour and citric aroma. Very pleasant. Tart, earth, smoke, sourness and some light fruit in the flavour. Has a grape aftertaste. Very good one. Thanks Jacob for sharing.

From jug at the brewery. Pours hazy dark orange with a fully gone head. Aroma is citrusy and crisp hoppy. Smooth furity, crisp bitter and mild peachy to citrusy. Medium dry and lingering fruity finish with a subdued tartness.Earlier Rating: 7/3/2008 Total Score: 475 cL bottle, brewed in 2005. Pours hazy orange and with a white, semi-lasting - slowly diminishing with a nice lacework left. Aroma is mild orange fruit and nicely blended with a dry wood and brett-citric aroma, dry horseblanket too. Dry wooden initial flavour. Hops seem to completely gone. Shows a nice citric flavour following this. Mild sulphorish note before the finish. Smooth and balanced wood and delicate fruit flavour into the finish. Seems to have a bit of bitterness into the far finish.

(Draught at Akkurat, Stockholm, 4 March 2011) Hazy golden colour with frothy, white head. Tart, citric nose with notes of grapefruit, unripe green grapes, sweaty socks, stable and barnyard. Tart, fruity taste with grapefruit, green grapes, stable and a dry, harsh, tart sourness in the finish. Medium body, very dry. Very tasty and refreshing. Excellent gueuze.Earlier Rating: 3/11/2006 Total Score: 3.8(At Akkurat, Stockholm, Mar 10) Pale amber colour, with almost no head. Complex, earthy, sour nose with hints of old socks (yes, very nice!). Taste is well balanced: sour, mature, earthy, musty with hints of citrus (tangerine, mandarine). Some fresh hops as well. Very nice!

(Bottle, 0375 l, at Kaisla on 2010-05-29 and draught at Pikkulintu on 2010-12-04) The beer poured golden and hazy. Its head was small and white. Aroma had fruitiness, grapefruit, sourness and citricness. Palate was medium bodied and dry with medium carbonation. Flavours were fruitiness, grapefruit, hops, citricness, wood and bitterness. Aftertaste was woody and bitter. A really good gueuze and as fresh the hops were pleasantly present. Earlier Rating: 1/11/2009 Total Score: 3.8(Draught at Akkurat, 2008 vintage, on 2010-11-20) The beer poured orange and cloudy. Its head was quite large, white and sparse. Aroma had sourness, fruitiness, hops and grapefruit. Palate was medium bodied and dry with quite high carbonation. Flavours were fruitiness, hops, grapefruit, sourness, tartness and bitterness. Aftertaste was sour and fruity. Very good gueuze. Surprisingly tart.

Bottle: Poured a hazy golden color lambic with a medium foamy head with good retention and some lacing. Aroma of funk and barnyard with some dry hoppy notes. Taste is also a funky mix with medium barnyard notes with well balanced tart and acidic notes and a dry European hops finish. Body is quite full with average carbonation. Very well brewed with hoppy notes mixing quite well with the tartness and acidity.

Bottle much thanks to Savvy1982. Pours hazy straw yellow with a foamy white head that fades leaving a small head. Aroma of lemon, herbal hops, grass, apple, generally sour yeast aromas. Taste has a solid amount of mouth puckering sourness, the dry hopping gives some herbal and floral qualities but is overwhelmed by the sourness for sure. There is a mild bitterness on the finish. Body is thin, low carbonation. Very nice beer. I will sip on this bottle for a couple hours.

Just realized this is now listed as a separate entry.  Vintage 2010 Sint-Gilloise  Special thanks to Todd for sharing!  Hazy cold pour with a spritzy white head and drippy lace.  Aroma is lactic with subtle hints of hallertau hops.  Clear, sour, refreshing and dry.  Lingering hop essence.  I could drink this stuff all day Earlier Rating: 8/8/2008 Total Score: 3.6Hazy orange pour. Well carbonated. tart aroma and flavor, acidic and a dry finish.  Notable hints of hops and citrus

750ml bottle from a trade with maltybones. 2010 vintage. pours beautiful golden with a lasting white head that lingers and laces. very fresh hoppy nose, dusty, fleeting tartness. not very gueuze like at all but quite nice. the flavour starts with lemony acid, a touch dusty, noticably hoppy, lingering long woody finish. crazy fresh and fibrant tasting for a gueuze. this is nothing like the other gueuzes ive sampled but its still a delight to drink. ill have to try it again after more time in the cellar.

Bottle from beer planet and from ølbutikken. bottled 04 october 2010.
hazy orange, huge almost white smooth offwhite head.
dry bretty champaigne like aroma, green grapes, a little grapefruit, a little wood.
flavor is sour, citrussy, dry, clean, refreshing, a little oak, simple but very perfect and flawless (regarding what i like with a lambic). extremely drinkable.

UPDATED: FEB 26, 2011 Bottle. 2008 vintage. Poured into a DFH tulip glass a cloudy golden orange color with a coastered white head. Super clean aroma with lemon, peach, straw, some barnyard, and really slight hops. Drinking this is really close to a perfect dream. Light mouthfeel with good carbonation. Lemon zest start with some sweetness, minimal hop bitterenss in the end. Slight funkiness but nice balance to the overal fruit tart fruit notes. Peach fruit flavors as well. Overall, this is just a fantastic beer, clean and crisp with a really nice flavor.

UPDATED: SEP 11, 2016 Bottle at Beerbistro, a bargain at $30.  A geuze for intermediates, this is a smooth drinker.  Aroma still floor cleaner and funk, sweat and arsenic.  Light orange body,  medium mouthfeel.  Not too hard on the palate initially, a key for beginners.  however it is there hours after.Fruit and ginger and apple.

into  a HFS tulip @50. Pours a slightly cloudy golden brown color  with a decent sized head that holds for a bit but dissipates quickly. Smell intense of barnyard and spicy earth hops. lots of lactic in the smell that is mouth watering. taste is lactic sourness that gives way to a bit of malt complemented by bit of spicy bitter hops. finish is sour and mostly dry. mouthfeel is medium body that has a moderate carbonation. overall this is a beer that i wish had a higher availability.

750 ml at brickstore.  2009.  Tart and funky with spicy notes and hints of oak.  Pours golden blonde with a thin white head.  Dry and funky with a great tartness and lemon flavor, herbal hoppy flavors with earthy notes.   Excellent!
UPDATED: MAY 6, 2012 75cl, as Cuvée Saint-Gilloise, new exclusive brew Anno 2010, from De Hopduvel Gent, complex sour brew, yet easy to drink, balanced, hazy, good head, good brew, yet expensive!

750ml bottle, under the name Cuvée Saint-Gilloise, amber-gold color, with a white head, mild yeasty, bretty, funky, citrusy, horseblanket nose with a dusty, cobweb accent, with some light sour green apple, acidic zestiness notes within a faint barnyard aroma follows through on a medium-bodied palate with a yeasty, funky, bretty, dusty, sour green apple character with a tart, acidic, juicy lemony flavor with some zesty lemon rind, tart undertone, leading towards a sour citrusy, tart, acidic finish. Less sharp that i was expected.

Bottle from IPB. 2010 Sint-Gilloise.
Appearance : Clear peach colored with a small head.

Aroma : Citrusy with quite a lot of funk and oak. Light hops. 

Taste : Citrusy and woody. Light hops. Quite tart.

Overall : Pretty straight forward but quite tasty. Very nice funk. Maybe a bit too much wood on the nose. Nice tartness. Curious to see how it will develop with age.

750ml bottle. Lightly hazy golden yellow with a small white head. Aroma of bretty horse blanket, oak, lemon, herbal hops and some wheat. Flavor is very tart and sour upfront with some light bitter hop and malt qualities. Light body with sparkling carbonation and a long, clean, dry finish. Excellent beer, very sour but so smooth, clean and refreshing.

Bottle.  Hazy golden brown with a fluffy white foam.  Aromas are light base biscuit malts followed by plenty of barnyard and cheese notes.  Lemon with floral, grassy notes.  Bready, spritzy yeast with brown sugar.  Flavours are bitter, sharp and sour lemon and grapefruit with soft cheese.  Some quite Orvalian orange aspects.  Green, woody, floral, piney hops are a nice addition and rounds off a very nice beer.

Bottle shared at Pauls Thanksgiving tasting. Pours a hazy gold with a white head. The aroma has some bretty funky notes, light lemony notes and wood. the flavor is nice and tart with some lighter funky notes, some fruity almost lemony notes and a dry finish. Solid.

Bottle, shared with Dave. Very hazy orange gold, lively white head, no lace. Funky sour aroma, lactic notes. Sour, pithy, fruity (unripened stonefruits), mild lactic acidity. Quite young in character (no leather, no mustiness or cobwebs). Puckeringly tart (sour) finish. Yum!
user_location: the land of bitumen, beef & beer, Alberta, CANADA

text: UPDATED: SEP 20, 2014 Tap at Scheras at Zwanze Day 2014. Hazy light orange pour with a spotty white head. Amazing aroma of citrus and barnyard funk. Lively palate. Killer beer.

Highly malty aroma (for lambic) with minimal tartness.  Hazey golden with a hint of white bubbly head.  Very tart initially with a nice pale matliness behind it and subtle hop notes.  Interesting how it transitions from tart to malty.

Notes:  Pitcher-poured  at Nov 10 open-brew day, labelled "Cuvee Saint-Gilloise"

Draught at Akkurat, Stockholm. Yellow/golden color, small head. Sourish fruity aroma, grapefruit, sweetish notes, some rubber. Sour fruity flavor, mango, grapefruit, rubber and nuts. Huge bitterness. Fruity, grassy, sourish grapefruit finish.
Bottle. Clear yellow with a thin head. Aroma is funky with horse blanket, malt, and herbal hops. Flavor is acidic and sour with herbal hops, and mild bitterness in the finish.

Tap at Akkurat 9.9.2010. 
Murky golden. White creamy head that turns into a film.
Aroma contains berries, wood, vanilla.
Sour, acidic even lactic flavors. Crisp.
Astringent. Medium body. Medium carbonation.

UPDATED: DEC 15, 2014 Bottle shared by Ari, thanks! Poured a cloudy light gold with a thin white head that nearly completely dissipated. Aroma was full of sour fruits with a nice supporting funk and a hint of spice and hops. Flavor was full of sour fruits as well which were a bit more acidic on the tongue. The sour fruits were complimented by funk, spice and just a bit of hopiness. A great beer.

Outstanding funk! Love the aroma! So much old funk barn!! Citrus, lemon, FUNK!!! Love it!! The flavor is just more great funk, but the sourness is quite tame compared to many other cantillons ive had. Its still awesome though!

Draft.. Hazy light copper pour , tight white head , excellent lace . Light hop , fruity , woody , brett citrus aroma .  Flavor is sour , notes of lemon , touch of hops and funk . Medium bodied and carbonation . Nice drying bitterness in the far finish .

On-tap @ Akkurat.

In a tall tumbler this looks like a hefeweizen, straw-colored and cloudy. But it smells like an infected IPA with all the grapefruit bitterness, sweet malt, and lactic acid. Yet it drinks like water.

Jean Van Roy may now call this beer Cuvée St-Gilloise because the soccer team for which he brewed it is no longer on top, but if Cantillon brews you a beer youre always a champion in my book.
user_location: The Court of the Crimson King, California, USA

text: Bottle - Yellow-amber pour with a nice white head. Decent funk on the nose, with citrus, earth, and light manure. Dry and citrusy, orange rind, smooth malt and lots of lemon, grapefruit, and vinegar. Not over the top sour, but pretty tart with a lingering sour finish. Didnt get much hoppiness, but this was a 2008 vintage, so they may have been gone. Smooth and nicely carbonated. Could drink this all day.
Pale orange color, funky sweet barny nose, sweet tart sour funky flavor all at once, some pear, very round tart mouthfeel, fuzzy in my mouth, fantastic cantillon example, Ill take a barrel full

On tap @ Akkurat. Pours orange. No head. Notes of black currant seeds, citrus and sour berries in aroma. The taste is sour at first, then fruity (apricots etc.). The finish is quite hoppy for the style and offers a small bitterness too.

bottle - (asheft) hazy orange beer with no foam. Aroma is very fruity and has a strong  vinegar note, but also decent hops hints. Flavour is fruity with a nice grapefruit touch. Nice sourness, very refreshing. Low bitterness, low carbonation.

[bottle]
Musty grape aroma with some woody and citrusy hops. Hazy dark yellow-orange under white wisps. Mouth puckering sour white grape and woody lychee flavour, with a potent grapefruit note coming in at the end. Light body, medium carbonation, sweet and sour finish.

Its hard for me to not give a perfect rating to any Cantillon offering, but I dont, anyway.  This one isnt as tart as some of the others, but it is almost perfectly balanced.  In an ideal world, this would be an everyday beer, not just a rarity.

2009 750ml bottle shared by furiousdman. Nose is tarty with a mild horseblanket note, citrus, yeast, and light spiciness. hazy yellow orange with a big white, heavy lacing head. Flavor is tart lemons and yeast; finish is tart with very light background bitterness.

UPDATED: AUG 15, 2011 The aroma is tarty, sweet, and smooth on the palate. The golden orange haze color with the white head is awesome. The tart flavor is smooth and delicious on the palate with a dry ending.

(St. Gilloise) Golden yellowish color, small white head; aroma is sour, salty and sweaty, earthy, slightly citrusy and woody; flavor is salty, grapefruity, moderate sour and light bitter in the finish; body is medium with low to moderate carbonation. Not very very sour, but on the other hand creditably complex and quite admirably balanced for a lambic.
Draft: Apple and apple core aroma. Cloudy golden, no head. Tart and musty with only a subtle apple character.

2008 bottle sampled 2010.

After leaving a bottle of the original batch behind, unopened, in a Copenhagen hotel room, this became something of a white whale for me for several years. Fortunately, its turned into a regular offering albeit not one distributed to WA state. I finally tracked down a bottle on a trip to Oregon and am tasting it now in another hotel room after watching a day of World Cup football. 

Elegant-looking beer; hazy yellow pour with a refined and long-lasting white head. Beautiful. Restrained nose, a bit of barnyard and cheese abut laid back by house standards. Beautiful tart flavor, not powerfully sour. Nice oak, white grapefruit, lovely blending of the aged hops with the funk of the beer.

on tap at ChurchKey in DC on 6/5/10.  Arrived a dark yellow with a small white head. Tart nose with some farmhouse funk. Medium body with light fruit notes, citrus and more farmhouse. Dry sour finish. Yummy.

2010 vintage under the new name. Poured into a Cantillon tumbler. Light straw colour, excellent clarity with a robust one finger white head that quickly subsides into a light foamy layer. thick inconsistent lacing. Nose- green apples, lemon, minerals. Taste- very lively juicy lemons, slight grassy hops, earthy. Not as carbonated or sour as past vintages which was forshadowed by minimal pop from the cork on opening. These might need some more time, or could be a dud bottle. Still carbonated but not what I expected. None the less, drinkability is off the charts.  Finish has more oak and dry hopping noticable.

On tap at Churchkey, 6/5/2010.  Pours a hazy whitish golden color with very thin head, makes me excited about lambic to see it.  Aroma is tart, musty citrus, with lemon peel and some citrus hops.  Flavor has lots of lemon peel, grapefruit peel, tartness, barnyard funk, and a bit of citrus hop.  Finish is sour with lemon peel bitterness.

(Old BA rate - bottle)
Light marigold color; poured with a thinner white head. Hops jump out at first; bit of hay; tart; bit funky as well. Quite wonderful. Nice stuff; not as hoppy as suggested in the nose; tart; citric; not that puckering or funky, though. Thinner to medium body; a bit chalky and dry; subtler carbonation. Pretty darn good drinking as I enjoyed the dryness

2008 Bottle - Thanks JohnGalt1!! - Pours a translucent golden with a medium sized frothy white head...aroma is herbal and grainy, lemon, wood, earthy...flavour is similar, tart grains, tons of lemon, buggy and woody with a consistent earthy dirtiness...the citrus is very pronounced, and I could have probably drank this all to myself...

2009 750ml caged and corked bottle

Appearance: The body is btw straw and golden yellow in color with a slick appearance. Carbonation is minimal, the head is an off white 1 inch crown that shows little retention and leaves little lace.

Smell: Hops, barnyard funk, and a touch of urine soaked hay.

Taste: Same as nose. I had heard that the recipe was different for the new vintages (hops addition) and thats why I tried this bottle fresh. I figured lets try it while the hops are shining. Well the sourness/tartness is minimal when its fresh but it fuses nicely with the hop treatment. Different and well done.

Mouthfeel: On the lite side of medium bodied with minimal carbonation.

Drinkability: Low abv and not very sharp....so easy to drink.

If you are looking for that classic "Cantillon Sharpness" that will make you pucker, this isnt the right Cantillon for you. This new recipe is quite sessionable.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 09-10-2009
Draught at Akkurat. A nice thirst quencher in the hot weather. Very sour and with lots of fruits, specifically apples. It was like drinking raw alcoholic fruit juice.
Cloudy bright orange appearance with a large white head. aroma is of funk, citrus, and grain. Taste is sour with some citrus and a light funk.
bottle thanks to blutt59.  poured hazy yellow with a white head.  aroma was lemon and some good tartness.  flavor was lemon, sour grain, and pretty dry.  body was rather light.

Green 750ml bottle at Toronado SF.  I was turning the big 27 and figured Id spring the crazy $35 for this bad boy to share with a few of my doggs.  The blend of champions, this is.

Pours clear golden with a one-finger white head and some good lacing. 

Aroma is sweet malt, wild tartness, and funk - your usual Cantillon smell - as well as floral hops, which are a nice touch here.

Flavor is typical Cantillon as well.  Pale malt, their usual awesome wild yeast, and barnyard funk, with light fruits (pineapple/citrus) and floral hops.  This was a fairly fresh bottle (less than one year old), so the hops really came out.

Medium body with pretty mild acidity for a Cantillon beer.  This is not overwhelmingly sour.

Great beer overall.  Id like to see Cantillon make more forays into the hopping arena, although they should use some darker bottles if theyre going to do that, or the beers could become major skunk-o-ramas.  A Cantillon IPA sounds amazing.

WOW! Bottle shared at Belmont Station...  Poured golden/orange with a white head.  Funky, brett, horse blanket, dusty/musky aroma.  Dry, very dry, acidic and tart.  Peppery, hot with sourness.  Vinegar, candied sweetness similar to a puckering warhead candy.

750 ml bottle; thanks Tom!!  Nice to get another crack at this via the bottle; 2008 vintage; muddy yellow with thin white head; fruity with dry lemons and thick texture; dry, grassy hops with lovely light cheese gueze; yummy; would love to sit down with a whole bottle myself some time

Original Rating 5/23/08 - draft @ brouwers sour fest - pale yellow and cloudy with white head; lots of carbonation; aromas of lemon, pineapple and yeast; drinks sharp and crisp with lots of zing in your mouth; flavors are sweet and sourness is muted; this was my fav of the cantillons sampled at the fest

UPDATED: MAR 14, 2011 Labelled as Cuvee St. Gilloise. Bottle. Pours hazy gold, with a thin white head, poor/spotty lacing. Nose is mildly sweaty, floral and earthy hops, delicate, with some "juicy" character, though perhaps not as much as in their standard Gueuze. Flavors are quite earthy, and at colder temperatures, almost too sharp, the dry hopping is extremely apparent, revealing itself as an earthy, though well-integrated aspect as the beer warms. Nice tartness, good earth, and a mild "sweaty" character that will doubtless improve as this one ages. A solid effort, though I think I honestly prefer their standard Gueuze.

Re-rate March 14, 2011: Bottle has evolved to a Much greater extent. Very sour now, and extremely sweaty, a much juicier, cheesier, and overall superior experience. Re-rate to 4.1, averaged to 3.9.
Pours hazy amber. nice carbonation. Musty funky slightly sour aroma. Flavour is very bold and sour with a dry finish. This is a great gueze lambek. Citrus and sour and funky just great.

Draught at Moeder Lambic Fontainas, Brussels. Golden with frothy white head. Nose and flavour of ripe fruits, wood, barnyard, very earthy. Aggressive funk that finishes very dry and tart. Interesting gueuze but unblended its pretty full on.

Serving: 750 ml. bottle from Hi-Time Wine Cellars.
It pours a light gold color with a very effervescent white head.  The nose is slightly sweet with notes of oak, apple, and light caramel.  I dont get much on the sour side.  The taste is very oaky with notes of lemon, a slight pithy bitterness, earth, wet hay, paper, mushrooms, and apple.  The body is very light leading to a very dry but short finish.  Medium to highly carbonated but still soft.  Overall pretty solid for the style and worth having a glass of.

Grabbed a light, springy, fruity beer to celebrate the rising of our lord. Pours a muted orange color with a quickly dissipating white head. The carbonation is significant though. Fruity and funky aroma. Funk is of the must and hay variety as opposed to a stinky cheese sort of variety. Grassy, hay aroma as well. Flavor is a lot of tangy lemon citrus with a bit of sourness. The finish is nicely bitter rounding out the drink. You are left with a stinging sort of sourness on the back of your palette for a while after the last swallow.

Tap at Blind Tiger. A pretty wild beer this. Potent aroma of unrelenting funky yeast. Flavor is sour and acidic with grassy notes. Finish is very crisp. Medium in body with good carbonation, which enhances the sour bite. A nice departure from my normal fare.

Served as Cuvee du 89. Rusty cap with wet cork under. Pours a straw moisty yellow with a white head. The nose is acidic with sour notes off cause. Im thinking of soap to clean the dishes with....the strong version. The taste is not that sour and fades rather quickly. Grapes that are not that green anymore. I sence some woody notes as weell Watery to medium palate.

A: Pours a light golden yellow hue with a small white head.

S: Nice bold funkiness. Lemon and wet grass stand out. Dank basement and cheese.

T: Tart apples and lemon up front. Wet hay and wonderful funk. Crushed sweet tarts and a nice blast of acidity.

M: On the light side of medium, nice tartness (not overly) with a grassy hop bitterness.

D: Darn good, man Cantillon does no wrong.

Draught @ Brouwers Café during Big Wood 2008: &nbsp Straw colored, a little bright even being hazy, moderate frothy white head, decent lacing, lively carbonation. &nbsp Sweaty nose, sock and underarm. &nbsp Funky! &nbsp Also barnish and floral. &nbsp 

Somewhat of a straight up tartness on the tongue but without many other flavors. &nbsp Dry, and very simple. &nbsp Perhaps a little bright floral aspects. &nbsp Not as big as I was thinking it would be. &nbsp Flattens out on the 

backside. &nbsp Moderate body and mouthfeel. &nbsp Needs more umph at the finish.

Thanks Flacoalto.  2004 vintage.  Lemon juice, hay and smiles.  Hazy mustard.  Stinging in my jaw tart.  Bracing.  Eyes roll back.  Reminds me of my first Iris.  Maybe some strawberry essence in there.  Glorious.

750 ml 2005 bottle.  Pours a deep orange caramel with a frosty off white head.  Aroma of sour oak, funk, citrus and grapes.  Taste of sourness, oak wood, funk, citrus and grapes.  One of the better sour beers Ive had.

750ml bottle, brewed Jan2007, bottled 19May2009.  Pours a slightly hazy light golden yellow with a moderate bright white head.  Aroma is lovely barnyard, musty, dusty, fresh citrus and lemon, fresh cut and peel, and oak.  Flavor is lots of fruit, peel, a good amount of sour and tart, oak, funk and general yum.  Wow, this works really well for me and found this to be unique and very, very tasty.  Great stuff!

750 ml bottle.  brewed in january 2007.  bottled may 19, 2009.  drunk late november 2009.  a clear orange/gold hued beer under a small white head.  mildly tart.  light and incredibly smooth palate.  peachy/lemony flavor.  a very clean gueuze.  dry finish.  quite nice.
Bottle from 09. Pours a golden color with a thin white head. Has a acidic funk smell to it. Has a mild sour taste with a little wood taste. This one would have been if it was older.

Bottle shared at Moosetoberfest. Poured a golden nectar yellow with a small fizzy white head. Aroma if super funky with some honey sweetness and smokey sourness. Funky sour aroma with lots of barnyard funk but not as sour as some of the other beers sampled. Good stuff that I should seek out and age.
Aroma is bold, sour, funky, barnyard and dirty rotten socks. Flavor is cheesy and rotten, dirty socks, moss and wood with some funky sourness. Bold and crazy cheesy.
Orange color, cloudy, and has a white colored head.  The smell is is tart, sour, wood, fruits, and funk.  The taste is sour, wood, acidic, tart, and funk. Nice.

750, 08, capped and corked. thanks sprinkle! pours a cloudy medium gold with a dense and creamy white head. moderate lacing. big lemony nose with tart white vinegar behind that. creamy medium body. tangy lemony, minerally, mildly tart mid palate. mild tangy finish. this beer is a perfect balance of refreshment and complexity. delectable.

Bottle from WTF OMG tasting in tampa. This one pours a hazy golden yellow color topped by a thin, bubbly white head that quickly settles to a thin layer of bubbles. The aroma is full of sour apricots, oranges and lemon to go with some grapefruit, oak, and bretty funk. The flavor follows with more sour oranges and apricots to go with a good dose of lemons and grapefruit citrus. Really sour taste in this one. Some oak and funk come through as well along with a touch of lactic creaminess to smooth things out. Medium bodied with subtle carbonation that balances the tart, dry mouthfeel perfectly. Another great lambic from Cantillon.
Draft: hazy straw color with a little white head, funky sour aroma and taste, mild carbonation, excellent beer.

Bottle shared at The Beer Engine.  Pours cloudy yellow with a thin white head.  The nose is vinegar, lemon peel, light funk and yeast.  The taste is lemon juice, light barnyard, malt vinegar and spicy yeast.  Medium prickly mouthfeel.  Good stuff.

CUVEE DE PETIT OISEAU a bottle 0.375L tasted at Pikkulintu. A 2004 brewed geuze bottled at 2006. Stored three years. Mild citrus nose. Pale head. Sparkling. Slightly hazy golden colour. Pale slightly pachy and lemoney taste. Slight bitterness at the end. An excellent one.

Bottle pours hazy golden color with white head.  Aroma is leather barnyard funk with some lemon and a touch of acidity.  Moldy mouthfeel.  Flavor follows the nose exactly and finishes smooth.  This is a very nice beer.  I just love these beers from this brewer.  Good stuff.

Shared at Where the Wild Beers Are 2009.  The aroma is sweeter than expected, tart, fruity, citrusy.  The appearance is a very slightly hazy light yellow, white head.  The flavor is tart citrus fruity, funk, some vinegar.  The finish again was like sour fruit candy.  Very nice.
Tap @ Ebenezers.  My first pour at Ebenezers produced a still-looking golden gueuze. Mild horseblanket and sour citrus aromas. Tart and dry with a slight funk.  Very refreshing.

Poured a peach yellow with ample foamy head. Nose is heavy with floral and slight horse blanket. 
Taste is sour, almost like a sour patch klid sour, slight vinegar, big citrus tart. Its like the Orangina of sours.
Tap @ Abbazia di Sherwood. Muddy golden with no head at all. Smells hoppy, spicy with all the range of funky notes peculiar to the style. Tastes bitter, hoppy, toward a sour end.

Bottle.  Pours a cloudy deep lemony yellow with no head.  Big funk, tart citrus peel, very very faint herbal hop notes in the background.  Lots of tart citrus and underlying funk dominating this brew.  Finishes very tart and dry on the palate.

Tap @ SDBF09. My favorite of the beers on tap for the day. Was interesting to see the difference of a gueuze blended with 3 two year old lambics rather than the usual method. Definitely a must try.Great flavored gueuze with citrus and funky sour notes.

Bottle shared by Shyam -- thank you!  Pours a hazy apricot color with a trim off-white head.  Smells of sour funkiness and potpourri.  Very approachable and balanced in flavor for a sour.  Tastes of underripe oranges, floral hops, tart fruit and lemon zest.  Well done.

Bottle graciously shared by Shyam.  Cork said 2008, consumed a year after he purchased it.  My great thanks.  Finishes what Iris starts.  Nose is an earthy funk with that jasmine-like delicate floral quality that is ridiculously unified.  I want these guys to dry-hop my corpse because these are the most beautiful hops in the world.   Flavor is more of the same and what results is a sour that is so fresh it is unlike fruit or vinegar or wine - maybe I was being unobservant but I feel it is a perfectly unified floral sour.  Really something.  This will be the one I keep around.

2003-2004
6/19/2008:  Cuvée des Champions appears to be clear and is light copper in color with a frothy, soft, off-white to light beige head.  This beer smells like a "wet horse blanket".  It is sour, tart, acidic, and has lots of vinegar in both the flavor and aroma.  However, it is surprising balanced and smooth.  Overall it is very good.

75 cl bottle (Alc. 5% vol.).  Rating #311 for this beer.

@Pauls Girardin chugging courtesy of nickls-750ml bottlepours a white ring for a head and hazy yellow/orange color.  Aroma is tart fruit-lemon, vinegar, light malt, dry.  Taste is tart fruit-lemon, vinegar, light malt, dry.  Easy effervescence.

750ml bottle.  Big thanks to drewbeerme for breaking this one out.  Pours a clear orange with a thin head.  Aromas of sour/tart fruit touch of grains, citrus and slight funk.  Tart fruit flavors grains, funk, citrus, and oranges, that are bitter and sour.  Acidic but drinkable.  Really tasty.
Very acidic and concentrated one, much like a sour lemon juice. Finish is offcourse dry and extremely acidic, close to harsh but still so tasty, sharp and really clever if that makes any sense.

UPDATED: DEC 13, 2012 750mL. Bottled January 2008. Even from the neck of the bottle, this beer throws an amazing aroma. Cottony, honeysuckle-scented perfume wafts through tart lactic and citric acids, bringing a steady stream of fresh salty warm breezes. Strong and beautiful. Pours a stunning near-crystal-clear peachy shining golden, with a rim in soapy, heavy lacing pure white. Gueze is good. Tart, vibrant, alive and lightly white-grape vinous. Dry, oaked, and crisp. A bit of bearberry and lemon acids come through. The sugar palate isnt as soft and creamy as other versions, but this has a stunning pale nectarine and peach fruit profile. Balanced. The funk level lays a little lower. The carbonation is a bit softer than I expected. Finishing, this beer gives a fireworks glow or ruby, golden, and white grapefruit pulp and zest. So wonderful, so wonderful. I like the youthfulness of this example.

[email protected]/* <![CDATA[ */!function(t,e,r,n,c,a,p){try{t=document.currentScript||function(){for(t=document.getElementsByTagName('script'),e=t.length;e--;)if(t[e].getAttribute('data-cfhash'))return t[e]}();if(t&&(c=t.previousSibling)){p=t.parentNode;if(a=c.getAttribute('data-cfemail')){for(e='',r='0x'+a.substr(0,2)|0,n=2;a.length-n;n+=2)e+='%'+('0'+('0x'+a.substr(n,2)^r).toString(16)).slice(-2);p.replaceChild(document.createTextNode(decodeURIComponent(e)),c)}p.removeChild(t)}}catch(u){}}()/* ]]> */ Bier Circus, Brussels. Slight hazy golden with a nice white lasting head. Aromas of vinegar, musty, salty and woody. Flavor is tart, dry, matured and rubbery.
Special thanks to JMFG.  Lots of funk in the nose.  Lemon, must and other citrus.  Flavors like funky, dusty, grapefruit.  Awesome.
Pours yellow no head. Sour lemony nose. Citrus and lactic acid. Flavor is puckering, vinegary, tart citrus. Lovely.

Bottle.  Pours a golden body with a white head.  Tart citrus acidic with some funky notes.  Grapefruit mouth puckering lightly woody with a tart finish.  Awesome brew with a light lactic acid character.  A great brew.

750ml bottle at Novare Res.
Could it be, my new favorite beer?!  This is friggen amazing stuff.  The dry hopping gives it a nice hoppy aroma in the glass in addition to the aged hops, and wild yeasts its a wonderful nose.  The flavor is heavenly, sour, sweet, and tangy.  This is a perfectly put together beer, a bottle Ill never ever forget.
excited about this ... pours a clear lemon juice ... good lacing ... very wild stuff, a champ .. very intresting .. mouthfeel is a tad watery but makes it wickidly drinkable .. a nice brew ...

750ml Bottle (Bottled 1/10/06):  Aroma of tart fruit, light funk, slight orange, acid, Brett, slight fruit nectar, and oak.  Poured amber/gold/orange in color with a tiny white head that lasted around the edges.  Cloudy.  Sparkling.  Full of small particles throughout.  Flavor is very tart.  Tastes of tart fruit, pineapple, candy, oak, apricot, tangerine, wood, slight candi sugar, slight funk, and a hint of hops.  Light to medium body.  Thin, dry texture.  Average carbonation.  Tart, puckering, fruity, oaky finish is dry.
Bottle at plan B. Hazy golden body, with a medium white head. Aroma is hay, citrus, sour and cellar. Flavor is dry grape, cellar and some pineapple.

Bottle. Hazy golden with a large champagne like white head. 
Aroma is hay, dry citrus and "old cellar like", typical Cantillon. 
Flavor is mostly dry dusty acidic grape, with hints of pine, and it has a strong tart finish. 
Not as harmonized as the others Cantillon I have tasted, its to acid.

01/10/2006 vintage, almost three years in the bottle. Nice golden color, sports a white head but quickly becomes semi-still, smells like a hint of cobweb, tastes wheaty and sour lambic, citrus, especially sour lemons. Funky a bit but very drinkable, some cheese, I like it.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 11-05-2008 05:41:52

Pours a bright golden with a lasting, half glass full, egg shell head. After it finally subsides, the nose is huge with tart citrus, barnyard funk. The flavor is a bit more mellow, but follows the aroma. Lively mouthfeel.

750 ml bottle at Akkurat.
Cork marked 2006.
This is a good gueuze, with a very lemon tasteing sourness! Interesting and nice hop finish.

Enjoyed out of flutes. Poured opaque, golden-xanthous with a silken appearance, minimal head. Quite a pungent nose. Sweet citric sourness combined with a sparkling champagne makes a tart aroma which throws your nose through a loop. The favor contains the initial sweet and sourness aspects of the aroma but then softer coniferous hops soothed into reassuring oak. There are hints of champagne, apple, spruce, hay, vinegar, lemon, earth, and candi sugar all the way through. The palate is quite appetizing as well; smooth like fresh juice without the weighty pulp and perfect light carbonation that subtracts nothing from the character and complexity of the flavor. I want to say, having never experienced Cantillon nor a gueuze, this beer is like getting punched in the face then rocked to sleep as you fall to the ground and enjoying every second of it. I have no other way to convey transcendental quality of this beer. Beautiful.

Thanks to cquiroga for sharing this one at the Lost Abbey Barrel Night.  Golden pour with a fairly mellow funky/ citrus aroma.  Tart and dry mouthfeel although not overwhelming.  Flavor is the typical citrus and barnyard funk that you find in a gueze but with hints of sweeter fruits.  All around, it was a unique and very enjoyable beer.

Bought at Bierloods.
Tasted with Marc, Leen and Paul last sunday 28.12.08.
Low-hazy golden color, with a thin white head. 
Aroma bit hops, woods-sourness.
Medium body. 
Taste nice sourness, fruity, good balanced bit woody. 
Dry finish.
Crushed with Jakebra.  Yup, good old mouth-watering mofo.  Citrusy, fruity, champagney, old man-y.  Sounds about right.

750 ml bottle, courtesy of the kind and generous golubj.  2008 vintage.  Clear gold color with a thin, white head.  Tart aroma, with hints of hay, citrus, and light hops.  Clean, dry, tart mouthfeel.  Mildly sour, with nice fruity undertones.  Finish is dry and astringent.  Very nice.  Thanks again golubj.

rbesg07 grand tasting, bottled. massively sour aroma - garbage juice, acid drops, apple vinegar and sherbet. slightly milder flavour than aroma - hints of rexona, lemon barley lollies, oak. delicious, rasping stuff

Review 500.  

Brewed in 2005, bottled in January 2008.  Poured into a Duvel tulip.  Gorgeous translucent gold with a touch of amber.  One finger of dense, compact, snow-white head that fades into a partial cap and halo.  Thin but solid sheets of lacing.

Aroma consists of lemon juice, crabapple, and grapefruit rind.  Sour but not really funky.

Flavor is similar.  Citric acid, big sourness, vinous/chardonnay notes, and an earthy finish that must be from the dry hopping.

This beer is medium on the palate with great carbonation.  A little sticky but still a pretty good mouthfeel overall.

Bottle, brought by cquiroga to the 2008 Lost Abbey Barrel Tasting Night. Earthy, soily aroma with plenty of oak and lemon citrus. Flavor is tart and citric with less funk than a traditional gueuze due to the lack of the young lambic addition. Bitter, hoppy finish with a grainy and earthy aftertaste, similar to that achieved with Saaz hops in some Belgian ales. Unexpected to taste it here in a gueuze. Smooth oak flavors blend well in the finish as well. Very unique.

Bottle, 75cl corked, at Plan B in Copenhagen. A slightly hazy golden beer with an orange tint. Some carbonation and a minimal white head. Funky, barnyardish nose wth citrusy acidity and some orange. Funky, barnyardish and citric flavor too, with some lemon and orange and an orange peel-like bitterness. Astringent and sour in the mouth with some carbonation. Medium full. Fine bitterness to compete with the sourness in the finish. Really easy to drink, especially considering it’s a Cantillon beer. Quenching and moreish. (080913)

Bottle:  Glowing golden pour with a thin white head.  Aroma is soft and mellow, but rich.  Taste is so balanced it blends together in a sweet and tart medley.  Good balance of oak barrel.  Indeed this is amazingly smooth.  Nice finish of lingering tartness.  Superb.

750 ml bottle.  Pours pale golden color with a pretty darn big white head.  Probably the biggest head with the best retention Ive seen within this style.  Aroma blasts with huge barnyard notes.  A bunch of farmy goodness, overwhelming Brett, horsey, hay, cobweb.  Also present is an intense phenolic character that is more reminiscent of Fantome than traditional Lambic, but it is a welcome addition.  Huge complexity in the nose.  Taste is brightly, intensely sour, nice acidity, bone dry.  This is pretty damn amazing.  I certainly cant think of a Geueze Ive had that is this good.  Sometimes examples of this style kind of blend together and all taste the same albeit good.  This one manages to hit all the classic notes but add an interesting twist.  Remarkable.

Bottle shared by Marcus. Color is orange tinged gold with a fine off-white head. Aroma is slightly citrus sour over mild light stone fruits. Near medium body with mild carbonation. Flavor is citrus, a bit sour like rind, and imaginable funk. A bit puckery. Finish is astringent and lightly fruity. After a long time it’s like grapefruit (flavor not hop).

UPDATED: JUN 24, 2009 750 ml bottle from La Cave å Bulles, Paris. One of the smoother Cantillons, and maybe appeals due to the upped hops content. Citrusy nose, decent thick white head, sparkling to the tongue. Like a fine Champagne in taste, but without so much fizz. Pucker inducing sour. One of the best gueuzes, and even slightly experimental.

Bottle from Plan b @ EBF. Hazy light golden, no head. Rose hip aroma, sweet mango and little mead. Baby food fruity flavor, mango and passion fruit, nice soft tartness, very easy to drink. Maybe not as crisp as I’d like, but very enjoyable fruity Gueuze.
oro buona schiuma discreta persistenza note fruttate leggero erbaceo un tocco dui aciditàa vino bianco in bocca acidità media ben frutatto un tocco di legno molto persistente al palato

UPDATED: OCT 8, 2008 Bottle shared by iowaherkeye, not pepsican. Poured a hazy golden-yellow color. Attractive aroma of funky white wine vinegar and lemon. Light bodied with mild acidity that peaked at the end. Tasted of tart apple, lemon, lime, and vinegary leather sandal. I never thought footy sandal could be such a pleasant flavor until I tried this beer.

Bottle.  It was my birthday today, and I had this while eating oysters at an oyster farm north of san fran; it was a really nice experience.  Cloudy yellow-orange pour with some white head.  Aroma is lemony tartness with a little bit of funk.  Very citrusy.  Flavor is the same, reminds of RR beatification, but not quite as good.  Small amount of sweetness in the finish.  It’s a good beer on a warm day.  I also put a little bit of it on an oyster that I cooked; it was pretty tasty eating.
Bottle at EBF 2008. Hazy golden colour with a small white head. Moderate aroma and taste of sweet sour fruits and citrus. Lasting finish. Well balanced.

Capped and corked 750. Pours hazy gold with a thick but falling head. Aroma of lemon, fruit, grass. Light body and moderate carbonation. Lemony taste of orange rinds, cork, barnyard, oak. Sour dry finish. I’m left with the taste impression of chewing on a cork that has been marinating in lemonade for a rather long time.

Cloudy pale golden, moderate head, really nice lacing and retention. Aroma is very funky with strong notes of cheese, also has barnyard action, lemons, a bit of basement. Medium bodied, moderate tartness, quite drinkable with a light sweetness. Nice Gueuze except for the price.

750ml corked [email protected]/* <![CDATA[ */!function(t,e,r,n,c,a,p){try{t=document.currentScript||function(){for(t=document.getElementsByTagName('script'),e=t.length;e--;)if(t[e].getAttribute('data-cfhash'))return t[e]}();if(t&&(c=t.previousSibling)){p=t.parentNode;if(a=c.getAttribute('data-cfemail')){for(e='',r='0x'+a.substr(0,2)|0,n=2;a.length-n;n+=2)e+='%'+('0'+('0x'+a.substr(n,2)^r).toString(16)).slice(-2);p.replaceChild(document.createTextNode(decodeURIComponent(e)),c)}p.removeChild(t)}}catch(u){}}()/* ]]> */ B, Copenhagen. Clear yellow brown. Thin greyish head. Fresh citrus-fruity nose with a slight sourness. Notes of cellar, hay and wood. Flavor is acidulous oranges, fairly tart with more  bittering hops than expected for the style. Some mineralic notes. Crisp. Dry citric, slight bitter ending. Utterly refreshing, high drinkabilty.

750ml bottle. Dull golden body with a nice, dense white head. Aroma has a pleasant, sourish,  musty cellar note. Flavor is acidulous, fruitiness in the direction of oranges with a bitter twist in the finish. This is a pleasant, well balanced, relatively kind, but still true to the style Lambic.

gold pour with a small white head.  Aroma of oak, dust, funky cheese,  lemons.  Flavor is up front dust,  cobweb,  dust,  grapefruit,  tobacco,  spice, metals.  Sour acidic finish,  lots of carbonation.

Cloudy ligth gold with noce lasting head. Ligth fruity hoppy aroma of grapefruit and leather, some flowers and spices. Flavour is sour and little bitter in the short sour finish. Supprisingly bitter and hoppy for a Cantillon.
RBSG 2008. Pours gold with a quick glimpse of a white head that vacates quickly. Dry and acidic with a long sour finish. Earthy and funky finish, soft lemony hop note to the finish.

bottle 375 ml 10 at Pikkulintu Helsinki 150808
golden yellow fizzy pleasant easy sourness , fruity, gentle hops. Some day I am looking more astringent Cantillon but maybe this bottle was matured for a while. Refreshing hot summer day.

Pours light golden color with smallish carbonated head.  Aroma of sour goodness with some funk/cellar notes.  Flavor is nice and dry, tart almost metallic.  Good offering from cantillon but not my favorite of theirs.  Could use a little more age perhaps to round out the flavors.

bottle thanks to bhops. beautiful deep gold color with a 2 finger white head.  great tart/funkness smell with quit a large sourness to boot on the nose.  very smooth on the palate with a great sweet/tart flavor.
Hazy orange body, white head.  Aroma is faintly sour, has some bretty funk, and a touch of lemon citrus.  Flavor is lemony sour with a dry tang, and a note of hops.  Tangy and effervescent body.
Bottle.  Yellow/orange appearance.  Small white head.  Champagne, coriander, citus in aroma. Flavor is light, fizzy, spicy, lemon, and sour.  Well carbonated.

Bottle. Pale amber beer with a whitish head. Acetic, vinegry aroma with oak and a bit of grass.  Tart, acetic, lemony flavor with wood and grassy hops. Medium bodied. Lingering tart, acetic, lemon with light orange, grass, and wood. Hops definitely there. Cork on bottle burst in half when opened.

25.4 oz, bottled 2005.  The last of my oceanside ratings; Bethany, DE.  Clear straw orange with a ring of white froth.  Nose is funky lemon pith with touches of honey, oak and basil.  Body is medium light and juicy with tiny carb.  Taste is sour lemon up front with cheese, maybe gouda, cranberry, apricot and cherry skins.

Poured a golden color with a nice white lacing.The funk on the nose was sweet.This had some funk to it with a grapefruit bite.This finished with a small funk bite to it.This was one the more enjoyable gueuzes I have had.

750 bottle from sloth, thanks man.  Pours clear orangey amber, with a small whitish head.  Woody, dry, toasty, earthy aroma, really interesting smells.  Tart, dry, vinuous, barnyard and cranberry.  medium body and gentle carbonation.
2008 Vintage according to the cork.  Almost champagne like effervescence.  Excellent lemony aroma with light spices; clove and mace.  Flavor is true to the aroma.  Very tasty.

Thanks to BDR.  Orange pour with a bubbly white head.  Light fruits and funk on the nose.  The aroma is wonderful.  Sour deliciousness.  Carbonation in the body.  The funkiness and light fruit are there in the taste as well.

2005 Vintaged cork, bottled in 2005, so brewed in 2002.  Got this a long while back in a trade and have been saving it to drink with my brother.  Shared with him and my girlfriend Cyn.  Pours golden orange with a bright white ring.  Nose is very funky, and very very good and supremely appealing.   Taste is very tart very funky with lots of fruit and some light hop bitterness that could remain.  This tastes amazing.

Bottled in 2008, brewed in 2005:  Pours a slightly hazy straw with 1 finger of head that dissipates rather qucikly but lingers on the sides of the glass.  Aroma is wonderfully complex apple cider vinager, tropical fruit, cellar character, and Cantillon funk, (once youve walked in the brewery its unforgetable).  As you get to the middle of the glass the aroma because more and intensly gueuze, lots of leather and cellar character.  flavor is just as complex, apples, citrus and specifically lemon.  leather as you draw to the finish as well as mustiness with some funk and horst blanket.  Nice presense of dryhopping as well.  the floral spiciness of styrians fits in well with the sour flavor on the back of the tongue.  lean bodied with excellent cabonation.  I love this beer, one of the best Ive ever had.

Bottle.   Pours a hazy straw color with a medium sized tight white head.   Aroma is lemon zest , floral, grapefruit, grass.   Flavor is lemon zest, sour apple, grassy, floral.   Palate is medium to light, medium carbonation, finished super tart and way too refreshing.   This was amazing to say the least!

Bottled, 2005. Someone sent this to me probably 2 years ago, I dont remember who. Pours a beautiful cloudy gold with awesome head. There is a lot of funk to this one, but also a very nice underlying lemony sweetness that adds a nice touch. Reminds me a lot of Cuvee de Castleton, albeit with a more authentic lambic flavor. The hops are faded at this point but add a nice mellow bite. Quite good. Way better than the standard Cantillon Gueuze.

On tap @ Falling Rock poured a hazy gold with a small lingering ivory head. Aromas of sour citrus, apple, light wood, light spice and light barnyard. Palate was light bodied crisp and tart with a dry finish. Flavors of sour citrus, earthiness, barnyard funk, cobwebs and mustiness with a crisp dry lingering tart finish.

On tap at Spuyten Duyvil Brett Fest.  Pours orange with no real head.  Aroma is not very strong, mostly of sour funk.  Flavor of lemon, slight sourness, and slight hop bitterness.  The hops add an interesting dimension to this lambic, but Im not sure they blended well with it.  The palate also seemed weak and unlike other Cantillons Ive had.  Tasted like an American sour ale/lambic-esque beer and didnt quite impress.

On tap at Spuyten Duyvil. Aroma of wheat, apple, lemon, maybe some other light fruits, funk. Flavor a little tarter with the same sort of notes, hops were just sort of there at this point in a sort of "balancing" way, to which my tongue asked "why?" Finish was an odd conction of tartness and bitterness, nearly astringent. To me it seemed like a backwards way to achieve flavors similar to brettified brews of other styles.
On tap at Spuyten Duyvil Brett Fest.  Hazy pale orange with ring head. Mild honey lemon aroma with funk.  Lemon tart flavor with grassy hop and funky tart finish.  Excellent.
tap at brett fest at spuytin duyvil in Brooklyn. Balenced beer, nice carbonation, dry mouthfeel, tartness more subdued with a bitter element to it.
ok i loved this. a departure in that the tartness is slightly less assertive and there is something of a bitterness to the back end.  typical funky aroma and a thin dry mouth feal.

On draft at Akkurat in Stockholm (Thanks Johan!) It was a blisteringly hot day in the capital and I desperately needed something refreshing to send me on my way back to the hotel. After the first sip I knew I had found the perfect drink and that I wasnt checking in anywhere anytime soon.
Invigorating grapefruit, lemon and lime tones - although more subdued than in other Cantillons I have tried - and of course the customary coutryside smells and puckering sourness and acidity. Clean, prickly carbonation and bitter dry finish.

Pours a hazy golden color with a white head. Aroma is funky, sweaty, brett, barn yard, cob web, tart, and tons of funk. Flavor is brett, funk, tart acid, sweat, barn, must, and a tart funky amazing finish.

this is an awesome gueze...tons of funk and lots of citrusy grapefruity rind and juice flavors....tart finish....wow...wish I could get way way more of this
06 vintage

Poured from a 750 ml bottle, vintage 2006.  Hazy mist of blonde appearance.  Feathery funk and floral herb aroma; lemongrass and zest, mildew and mold, cheese rinds.  Glowing citrus character in the flavor of grapefruit, lemon and lime, juices and rinds; a dried out, pithy bitterness and raging acidic fruit character wholly dominant throughout.  Dry herbal funk lingers calmly underneath all that rindy fruit character with a musty, blue cheese and vinegar stink that seems calm and strangely clean.  Spritzy and full palate; distinctive and commanding; finishes with a pleasingly sweet, tangy funk of goat cheese and lavender that rubs gently and dryly.  Beautiful balance in this seemingly simplified example.  Thanks Ryan!
On tap at Brouwers. Picture perfect! Orange with a full creamy head in a small tulip glass. Cheesy, spritzy sour scent. Sour citrus refreshing taste. Sourness sinks in. Tasty!

On tap @ Brouwers.  What is incredible about this gueze is its light and airy champagne feel.  The flavor is all there, with less acid intake!  Highly enjoyable experience, would love to taste what happens with some age in a bottle.

25 oz bottle, bottled in 2004, via hopdog.  First pour is a crystal clear dark gold body with a one inch fizzy white head that faded fairly quickly to a wispy partial covering.  Light visible carbonation.  The nose is funky and cheesy with some sweaty feet and musty damp cellar.  Theres a really interesting wet leather scent in there too.  A hint of some acidity, some oaky notes, and citrus rinds.  First taste is bracingly tart and acidic with lots of musty cellar and funkiness on the finish.  Its pretty one dimensional at first, all I get is lots of sourness, but everything really blooms on the finish.  Theres some crusty bread maltiness and a tiny bit of powdery sugary sweetness.  Not so sure I really get a whole lot of hoppiness.  Mouthfeel is tight and crisp up front with a little more of a softer nuanced finish.  Perfect slightly fizzy pinpoint carbonation.  A wonderful Gueuze to be sure.  Its really amazing to me that this beer can be so wonderful and still be roughly in the 80th percentile for the style.  Theres really alot of depth in the style.
From the Sour ALe Fest this pale yellow colour beer has a small white head. Tart and fruity aroma with a yeasty touch. Malty flavour with a light sourness and a spicy note.  Great stuff.

6 oz draft at Brouwers Cafe Sour Fest in Seattle, Washington.  Pour is hazy orange golden with not much off white head. Aroma of musty sour yeastiness, some citrus fruit - apple and pear. Taste of bright sourness, grapefruit, musty earthy yeastiness. Nicely bright and refreshing.  Finish is bone dry, very champagne like.  Beautiful sour.

Bottle at Pauls Hoboken Gathering: Hazy yellow with a white creamy head.Very complex nose of sour lactic funk, lemon-rind, some leather and other unidentifiable stuff. Fluffy crisp body. Very tart, borderline sour with some leather and sour fruit pit, tart grape-like fruity undertones and a very mild earthiness underneath everything. Bone-dry finish. Complex and outstanding.

On tap at Brasserie Beck.  ($14 a glass...envious of the folks getting it for $8 in CA).  This is stellar: aroma is funky lambic sourness, but also lots of grassy dry-hop aroma.  Flavor is pears, citrus, but then lots of herbal hop funk, with sourness coming in towards the end.  One of the best things Ive had to drink in ages.

From a 750mL Bottle.  Pours a transparent color of honey, topped with a thin head of wispy off-white.  

Moderately acidic nose, bringing out notes of mild vinegar, white grape skins, peach fruits, and hints of 

grapefruit.  Beneath the fruit and brighter acid lies some funky oak dryness, peppery spice, and mild aged cheese. 

 Light bodied, lightly carbonated mouthfeel with a bold acidity.  Plenty sour, along with some more cheesy funk 

and peppery spice.  A bright, fruity acidity dominates the flavor before leaving behind an exceptionally long, dry 

finish.  Good, but not nearly as complex or deep as some of the other Cantillon goodies.

On-tap at Churchills. $6.50/8oz. Geezus. Pours cloudy orange/yellow with a thin, crisp white headhead, bits of lace. Smell is subdued, slightly funky and touich sour. Tastes like fruit and flowers and then barnyard funkiness. Sour throughout, the funk mellows on the finish and fades to plain ole sournicity. Medium body, vibrant carbonation.
On tap at Churchills.  Smells great.  Funky peach sour.  cloudy yellow amber color.  Slightly sour.  Very dry.  Better with cheese, which I dont have right now.  Very good.

courtesy form mgumby10: pours a great golden colour very small white head. aroam is a great cantillion sour funk, fantastic fresh fruit, apple adn white grape. awesome. flavour is a great acidic sour perfect cantillion flavour. very citrrus grapefruit very good bitter tart finish

Courtesy mgumby10.  Darkish straw color, thin white head.  Tart aroma, but not crazy sour, classic Cantillon funk, herbs, slight sweet even.  Smooth, even taste - mild tartness spread throughout the palate, nice and dusty and citric.  Velvety and elegant.

UPDATED: SEP 29, 2009 Bottle, Merritt Island Throwdown. Thanks to Gumby.  Hazed orange color with small white foamy head. Leather, citrus rind, fresh citrusy twang. Perfect soft palate, makes me want to drink more. Gentle sweet grain nectar in background. Mature, refined, sophisticated, dry and delicious. Creamy smooth citrus zest. Excellent gorgeous smooth balanced gueze could drink it every day if I could.

Gumby, you are a baller.  This rarity poured a very hazy, light orange, perhaps apricot color.  The aroma is amazing, grapefruits, lemons, summer stone fruits, meadow flowers, and yes, that Cantillon funk.  The flavor is more than I expected, bringing me back to my childhood, beckoning a memory of grapefruit gummy candies.  An amazing balance seems to be found between the sweet and tart, the earthy and the funky.  Absolutely world class.

Pours a slightly hazy orange color with a small white head.  Alot of typical Cantillon sour funk and sweetened fruits show up in the nose.  Not overbearing sourness though.  The flavor had some typical cheek puckering sour tartness to it, along with some sweet fruits, grapes, and Chardonnay.  Lemons seem to be always noticeable here as well.  I got a touch of the hops in this beer, but it was certainly overpowered by the funk and sour that embodies this brewery.  Another great offering.

UPDATED: JUN 4, 2008 Merritt Island Throwdown 08: Bottle, courtesy mgumby10. Pours a hazy mango color, with creamy white highlights. Watery white head sits atop this gueze well. Nice sheets of lacing remain on the glass. Strength in the nose is the tartness, with a backbone of grapefruit and hops. Enjoying this combo. Big tartness flavor, with awesome barnyard qualities. Wheaty. The hops come in at the end, with a grapefruit finish. Easy as hell to drink, very well balanced. Hoppiness is refreshing in this one. Definitely liked the dry-hopping in this one.
Courtesy Mgumby10. Vintage 06. Pours a golden cloudy color. Aroma is mostly apple. Tastes of sour light fruits, with some funk yeast taste. Palate is refreshing with a sour kick. Thanks Mike.

Tasted at the February Northern California Beer Tasting. This lambic pours a deep yellow gold color. Large sized white foamy head. Aroma is lemon, sour, funk, must and a touch of sweetness. A medium bodied lambic. WOW. There is a lot of funk and a lot of sourness in this beer. Lively carbonation. It very very dry. Yet the acidity doesnt seem that bad. Tart, maybe thats the word for it, and then there is the funk. Nice beer. Mouthfeel is full and round. Finish is crisp and dry. Aftertaste is slightly bitter.

Bottled at Beer Circus, Brussels.
Hazy golden with a white head.
Really sour aroma; rubber mattress...
Soft palate but still very sour. Prett bitter.
3rd Annual Woodshop Tasting, 3/1/08. Thanks Chris!  Grapefruity, zesty lemon - tart forward.  Good amount of lingering funk.  Nice and drinkable - but powerful.

Sampled 7-19-2007. I believe this is my first unblended lambic. Pours a brown hued orange. Nose is slightly like a certain flavor of Ricola throat drops. I cant remember exactly what kind, but I think it was lemon and herbs or something like that. Antiseptic tone to it. Fair amount of wood is on there too. Flavor is sour indeed. Definite wood character to it. Just a pure mix of tart and wood. This is what a lambic is. Feel is as expected on the liquid and ripe with carbonation. Overall very drinkable. If you havent had a real lambic and dont appreciate that sour funk, you wont dig this one. This is a purists dream. Very much worth taking the bus to Philly for a day to get a hold of.

750ml bottled in 2006.  Poured into a flute the color is a bright light melon orange.  The carbonation isnt very active and there is no head.  Aroma is fruity sourness.  There is some funkiness but it isnt obvious.  The flavor is smooth and well blended.  Plenty of sourness, tart in the back of the throat.  Fruity and very acidic.  There is carbonation in the body, although the pour would never show it.

I like the idea of this beer -- to celebrate the local soccer teams division tile, and I like the way the bottle looks.  I kind of like the actual beer too.  Sharp acidity with the typical Cantillon tartness, thats kind of good and kind of unpleasant at the same time.  Has a kind of woody smoothness to round it out, which is nice.  Like many Cantillon products, its reminicient of eating grass, bread, and lemons, sitting out on a hilltop on a breezy summer day.

Bottle from the Blue Max.Pours a cloudy
color like Countrytime lemonade but this is not your daddys artificial sugarladen
piss-tasting lawnmower riding on a hot summer afternoon beverage.
Man, how can you describe a Gueuze?
Seriously? The funk is strong here young Jedi.

UPDATED: JAN 13, 2013 1/13/08. Aroma starts lemony and very acidic and then flattens out a bit with nail polish & funky cheese. Taste starts out salty and again flattens out a bit, bit still quite sour. 8/4/7/4/16 - 4.1

12/27/12. Glad I got a chance to revisit this my very first gueuze. Peppery nose. Funky, dusty, bitter grapes. Socks. Cheesy. Really bitter oddly enough. Vegetal, grassy bitterness that is. Did not re-score, but perhaps a slight bump over previous rating.

Aroma is nicely soured, kind of skunky and funky.  
Taste is very acidic, sour lemon, some rinds and mouth puckering bitter sourness.  Did I mention this was sour?
This shit is pretty good.  
Acidic, slightly harsh, drinks well, the hops make some presence, but only to give a touch of bitterness.  
Finishes clean, somewhat sour (again).
I also get a little BO and horse.

The beer that brought in the new year. Nothing better to have in a glass at midnight , toasting with friends, getting toasted. Poured hazy golden orange with a thin white head. Aroma is of typical cantillon yeast, barnyard funky, and hints of fruits. Taste was tart, but not over the top.  As "Stoutlover72" put it. It doesnt give you a "nut-check" like other cantillons. Very drinkable cantillon product.

06 bottle courtesy of miver.  Pours a hazy golden orange color with a small but dense white head.  The aroma is lemongrass, basement funk, and some light fruits.  Flavors are lemongrass, tart apples, pears, must, and some light hops.  Not as tart as most cantillons but it was a little young.

Another of the Christmas Eve beers shared by the family. This beer pours out a cloudy orange hue, with a fluffy white foamy head with some nice lacing. Aroma of lemonheads, aromatic cheeses, acidic, and a touch of wood. Mouthfeel is bright and lively with the liquid dancing on your tongue. Flavors was lemons, funk, Granny Smith apples, and stomach acid. Even with the acidity, its really nicely balanced and doesnt give you a nut-check like some of the other Cantillon products tend to do.
UPDATED: MAY 5, 2009 Copying from my tasting notes. Bottle. Orange pour with a giant white head. smell is off and murkey. taste is sour and fruity. nice and refreshing. very good

Bottles from Ughsmash and footbalm. Hazy golden-orange with huge white head, even after letting it breathe for quite awhile. Musty, sweaty, horsebalnket up front, big lemon tartness in the background. Flavor up front, tough to describe. I guess what sweaty feet must taste like. Funky cheese character, and then lemon/brett takes over. Mouth puckering sourness. Thirst quenching, finishes dry. Not as carboanted as I was expecting, soft billowy mouthfeel. Top notch geueze IMO.

Bottle (75 cl), thanks gnoff. Hazy golden with a large(!) white head. Green apples, some grapefruit, wood and faint horsestable notes. Light in body with soft mouthfeel. Not as dry as your usual Cantillon, and with a light peelish bitterness.
Pours hazy orange with tiny head. Grapefruit and classic lambic notes. Gentle bitterness in the end.

Bottle. A slight orange and musty pear fruitiness on the nose quickly fades into lemon zest tartness and the standard Cantillon funk. Pours cloudy peach with virtually no head. Flavor has some zesty pineapple at first with some mild funk notes chiming in later. More delicate and not as acidic as other Cantillons. Creamy on the tongue with a lot less bracing acidity and high carbonation than the normal house style. A most unique Cantillon.
From a bottle poured a hazy pinkish color with very little head.  Nice tart flavor with a strong quick finish.
Ácida, quase sem creme, avermelhada. Aroma complexo de uvas, maçã, acerolae madeira. Salgada no paladar. Corpo médio, extremamente seca.

Garrafa. Coloração vermelha clara, turva, com uma espuma bege de bolhas grandes, nem consistente, nem persistente. Cítrica, ácida, salgada, azeda e seca. Bom aroma, lembrando champagne. Trata-se de uma cerveja ímpar, que você pode amar ou odiar. Para mim, ela é apenas interessante.

UPDATED: MAY 7, 2015 Rerate, 750 ml corked and capped green bottle, as Cantillon Cuvée Saint-Gilloise. Cardinal Pub & Bar, Stavanger. ABV is 5%. Dry hopped with Hallertauer (which Hallertauer?) hops. Hazy golden to deep golden colour, moderate white head. Aroma of farmhouse / brettanomyces, pediococcus and lemons. Lemony and tart / astingent flavour, quite dry, hints of oak. Fairly distinct herbal hops in the finish. Original rating: Bottle, as Cantillon Cuvée des Champions, at RBESG 2007 in Glasgow, Grand Tasting. Cloudy golden colour. Very nice lemony aroma, hints of oak and barnyard. Lemony and fairly dry flavour, refreshing and nice.

Name: Cuvie des Champions
Date: 03/14/2007
Mode: Bottle
Source: Tasting

clear dark gold, wispy white head, sweaty funky aroma with tart lemon, big carbonated body, lots of tart lemon flavor, nice complex melody of flavors with nice funk, long sour finish

Aroma: 6/10; Appearance: 6/10; Flavor: 6/10; Palate: 6/10; Overall: 12/20
Rating: 3/5.0Drinkability: 7/10
Score: *4

Bottle, RBESG Grand Tasting 07. Hazy golden, thin white head. Grapefruity citrus gueuze. Mouth is quite sharp citrus with some straw, sourness then kicks in. Finishes quite smooth, but with that grating hop on the way down, just to cheer you up. Excellent

Clear yellow, hazier with the yeast in it. Fading head. Dry fruity aroma. Quite tart flavor with a nice bitter finish, the hops are really good here. Doesnt have that much aftertaste though. A normal gueuze, nothing special.

Golden-orange color with a small white head.  Aroma is thick and sour - very funky and acidic with some citrusy lemon, must, and sweet scents.  Taste is a pleasant sour citrus with some apple, raspberry, yeast, bread, wood. and assorted funky, but tasty flavors.  Very nice - wow.

Cloudy golden with a thin white head. Dry, acidic hoppy aroma, very pleasant. Light body, touch of bitterness doesnt clash too much with the sharpness of the acidity. Dry hops run through the flavour, very citrussy and quite sour. Apple skin tannin in the finish, pretty tart too. Challenging and enjoyable.
bottle Dark golden with a slight haze. Fluffy head. Sourish citrus zest aroma. Flavour is sourish/bitter citrus zest with a touch of iron.

One of several retired brews sampled at RBSG 07 Grand Tasting room. Pours a clear oranage amber brew with a fizzy white head that dissolves quite rapidly. Aroma of sour apples, yeast, lemon zest, and some barnyard mustiness. Taste is tart and heavily carbonated with flavors of sour apple, oak, and light caramel. Finish is tart, a little metalic, and then a dry aftertaste.

Damn this was good! Clear orange color with a thin white head. Lots of funk in the aroma with with some very very tart and sour notes. There is a bit of yeast and some sour apples n there as well. Very sour and tart up front with some acidicness and a bit more fruit.

Thanks to the tip from maniac that this was lurking in Charlottesville.  Pours a medium hazy copper with a slight head.  Aroma a complex medley of horseblanket, some cheddar, a touch of wood, and sour apple.  Flavor is almost a dead on match.  Complex, yet quite drinkable, not as aggressive as some other Cantillon brews, but still assertive.  Wonderful stuff.

UPDATED: FEB 27, 2008 Light haze swirls inside a room temp pour that glows a pale orange with golden, shimmering highlights. A small white head forms and slowly, then fully recedes. The aroma is very funky and tart, with notes of spicy yeast, sour fruits, farmhouse funk, soft sweetness, floral and earthy hops and no sign of alcohol. A cleaner Cantillon than usual, with glaring assertiveness and playful funk and tartness. The flavor is very sour, but is well balanced by bold earthy hoppiness and adequate sweetness. Funk intensifies and lingers longer with each sip. The fruit notes fade out after awhile, leaving spice and acidic notes behind, lightly burning the palate. The finish is mildly vinous, with lingering tartness and dry yeasty spiciness. Mouthfeel is soft, lightly to mildly carbonated and very enjoyable. A wonderful lambic. A shame its retired.

This was nice.  Experimental and sour.  Great barnyard, sour, acidic aroma.  Flavor was very sour like a Cantillon should be.  I tasted yeast and cherry, but the hops were very mild.  Light oak from the barrels.  A cloudy yellow beer.

UPDATED: APR 23, 2009 RBSG 2007.  So, I finally get to try this!  Awesome.  Pours to an orange caramel body with a white head.  The aroma is funky Gouda cheese, tart lemon zest, acidic lactic acid, horse blankets.  The flavor is ultra-tart lemons, pale malts, lemon zest, funky cheese, smoked Gouda, light white sugar sweetness.  The palate is tart but sweet.  Moderately tart.  Complex and not overly done.  Very nice.  Bring this one back Cantillon!!!


2004 bottle.  The beer pours to a murky amber body with a thin creamy white head.  The aroma is tart barnyard and sour kiwi.  Lemons, limes, and oak.  The flavor is nice pale malt gone sour with lemons and a soured kiwi.  Ultra-complex.  The palate is super sour and acidic.  Damn good.  Very "perfect".
RBSG 2007 Grand Tasting. Cloudy orange body with a small off-white head. Sour fruity aroma. Sour fruity flavor with some light caramel and spice and hint of lemon zest.
Sampled at the RBSG 07 Grand Tasting.  Perhaps my favorite brew of the evening.  hazy orange yellow color With earthy yeast on the sour nose.  Faintly sweet body with earthy sour finish.
Radiant gold, bit puffy white head.  Nose is slightly hoppy lemon candy, earthy woody yeast.  Flavor is very bitter lemon goodness, some hay, lemonhead w. most sugar removed.  Hay & lemon finish.

Perhaps the finiest gueuze iv ever tried? Spontanious weekend 07. Notes say: Less sour than standard canti gueuze, more balanced than a regular gueuze, hints of apple and lemon, perhaps not the most complex of gueuze, but just stupendous, i was gulping this down like there was no tomorrow, outstanding just an amazing alround brilliance in a glass.

On handpump at Bruxellensis beer festival, 9/10/06.  How I ended up here, I cant even describe., lets just say Jan at Cantillon goes above and beyond.  So anyway...  poured in my brandy new Bruxellensis tasting glass by someone who speaks English (yay says my ignorant, non French speaking self) and tells me this is a dry hopped Gueuze.  I shudder with delight!  Big huge earthy hoppy aroma that disintegrates into typical Cantillon funkiness.  First taste brings upon an onslaught of green leafy bitterness that holds off the barnyard for a few seconds only to succumb to the sour side.  So complex, so delightful.  Sitting in the sun at a beer festival somewhere just south of Brussels, drinking this nectar and about to embark on a 6 day beer tour.  I wanna go back.

Bottled in 2006. Cloudy orange with fine-bubbled white head that reduced to almost a film. Cheesy aroma, lots of wood, sharply acidic. Flavours are more acidic than ever, quite lemony, mingling mellowing cheese and dry woody flavours. A great geuze that is one of the more extreme of the bunch in terms of acidity.

Draught at Akkurat. Weird, I thought this was retired.. and to find it on draught at Akkurat. Might be a new batch? Anyhow, being dry-hopped, this will of-course remind you of Iris.. and it does. And thats a good thing.

Bottle from Capones.  Turbid golden pour with 1-finger white head.  The head is very fizzy and loud, and dissipate quickly, much like champagne.  The aroma is tart and funky, with some yeasty notes, and a peachy apricot hybrid being the fruit that comes to mind.  Tastes very tart, carbonated and lively on the tongue, with apricot, lemon, orange rind, and some earthy yeasty notes.

Poured a fairly clear golden color with a medium white head.  The aroma is why I drink lambics.  Leather and horse stable with some sweetness.  The flavor was a mix of acidic and sweet with nice yeasty character and a hint of bitterness on the finish.

UPDATED: APR 1, 2007 75 cL at Bier Circus, as Cuvee de 89. Glowing golden color, musty-sour aroma Lemony flavor is mellowed by an unexpected smoothness--which makes this IMO more accessible than most traditional lambics. If youre a hard-core gueuzer, this might be too light for you. Pretty damn enjoyable to me though. RE-RATED after another enjoyable taste the other day.
